review_title: GTS: great working environment, some major flaws.
pros:
Note: I can only comment on the Ground Transportation Department. Thales fully runs as separate business units. 

The project I worked on was interesting and, for the UK, industry leading. 

The staff from bottom to the project management were great, open and clear system for raising issues, supporting against customer complaints and HSE obsessed in the right ways. 

Overtime rates were great (x1.33 week day nights, x1.73 Saturday nights, x1.95 Sunday nights) making you want to jump on commissioning events, 37 work week, half day Fridays, decent enough personal tech. 

Obscenely good paternity package, all top notch health perks.

Had the chance to play rugby for the UK against France in Nice on a long weekend. A professional highlight for sure.
cons:
Bid teams cannot win bids. 
I was made redundant as there was a very large scale reorganisation due to not winning a major project in 5+ years. 

Weak requirement set up with customers - allow too much customer opinion after agreeing on a contract, resulting in loses for the firm against work agreed, then redone. 

Above all else, if you arrive at Thales GTS, from my experience any and all learning will be on the job. In 5 1/2 years, I was sent on one training course, one run by the company for a role I had been in for 2 years already. Very little training budget for UK staff. When your performance review comes in each year and you're being scored against a category of "[sic] personal development and acquisition of new roles and responsibilities" it's very hard to care after 5 years of saying "I asked for this software course for 4 years, I need it to take on that new stream of work, you approved it for the 4th year in a row, then it never happened. 

So, arrive at a level you're comfortable working and earning at for many years as upward progression in engineering is slow, very slow. 

From what I've seen, they do seem to be very good to contract for. Most contractors kept around for multiple years at good rates and they're not treated differently from fulltime staff in regards to working hours expected/pace of work and work/life balance.

pros: It's a job with health insurance and a paycheck. In this day and age, that is worth something.
cons:
Where do I even begin? Working at this company was a nightmare. 

Dysfunction at every level. If you value having work/life balance, then stay away from Thales.

Thales will work you to the bone because management is unable to manage workload and expectations. 

Management has no focus, strategy, vision, goals or ability to execute therefore everyone is spread so thin there is never any critical mass of resources gathered to accomplish anything. 

There is no team culture or collaboration, just pissed off people taking their stress and resentment out on each other. No cloud based collaboration tools - emailing powerpoints back and forth is considered peak efficiency.

Archaic processes, technology and most people there are dinosaurs stuck in their ways. No investment in digital transformation (Do NOT let their slick marketing fool you). 

You will waste so much time and energy daily with their outdated IT. My laptop, VPN, email, skype, two factor authentication, intranet, etc. were things I battled with daily in order to do my job. 

Deadlines and expectations are unrealistic, and stress runs rampant. Thales is a perfect example of a culture of "punished for competence". If you are able to produce, you will be loaded with more and more work until you are forced to leave to protect your sanity. 

Unless you are desperate for a paycheck (no shame in that by the way), then absolutely stay away. If you live in a "tech hub" city, then there is no reason to entertain the idea of working at Thales. There are so many other tech companies with culture, strategy, vision and ability to execute. Also, with how archaic their business processes and technology are, you will be actively making yourself obsolete. 

In conclusion, if you consider yourself a talented competent individual with options and who values innovation, do not even consider Thales.

My manager set the expectation and clearly defined my role early on and offered their time and energy to help get me up to speed with the team and company culture.  There are so many ways within the organization to receive guidance, education, training and direction that in my six months here I feel like I have a solid grasp of my role within the larger group.  I have already seen many opportunities for growth and career advancement for the future and feel like Thales really empowers their employees to succeed and move up within the organization.  

On top of all of this, Thales offers some of the best benefits anywhere in any industry.  Not only are the company benefits awesome, but the Thales InFlyt Café with onsite Starbucks allows me to get my coffee fix every morning!

review_title: Thales redefines software development, and not in a good way
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Irvine, CA
pros:
Steady paycheck.

Good work-life balance.

Great benefits.
cons:
Bureaucracy that puts Stalin's Russia to shame. Not uncommon for tasks to be blocked for weeks or even months when cross-department cooperation is required. New hire needs access to a network resource? Plan for at least two weeks for IT to flip a switch.

Everything extremely fragmented. Thales Irvine is like an ancient land of warring city states. Department A manager is at war with department B manager, so neither can get anything done, but they'll die before they give an inch even if that means missing their own milestones.

Management to developer ratio is insane. It's not uncommon for a single software engineer to work on a simple project with over a dozen managers. You'll have one poor guy writing code while being torn apart by infighting between project manager, product manager, product line manager, scrum master, product owner, customer manager, media manager, UX manager, UI manager, IVV, release train, etc. I am not exaggerating. 

No accountability (which management definitely considers a Pro). Fail to deliver a single line of code in months? Have every release rejected by screaming customers? No problem. There's always an offshore contractor with an unpronounceable name to blame while you get promoted.

Software development is managed by people with no software development experience or training. There's a lot of ceremony. Agile, daily stand-ups, scrum masters. It's all for show. Thales is hard waterfall, and very rusty at that. Developers are seen as little better than an inanimate assembly line with no capacity for rational thought. Here are your orders, here's how long you'll take to do it, now get to it. 

Many managers are toxic, and toxicity spreads. Better managers leave for greener pastures, or are squeezed out because they focus on work while their "enemies" focus on mooching up to upper management. I've seen intrigue that put medieval Spanish court to shame. And so good people are replaced by mediocre people, and mediocre people hire incompetent people, and eventually the snowball turns into an avalanche.

Pay well below market rates - senior management insists they pay market, but it comes across like they're being deliberately misleading. There appeared to be some movement to rectify this after a recent employee survey, though that seems to have slowed down.

"One size fits all" IT Policies can be stifling - Sometimes it seems like we spend more time working around ES than doing productive work. A Software Engineer needs more permissions than a receptionist.

Annual review procedure - Forced fitting to a bell-curve. This is a horrible process, it forces some people on failing projects  to get better results and raises than most of the team on a high-performing project. Fixed size buckets of money, each team is given a set value of raises to distribute. All this promotes hostility within a team instead of cohesion. If you're aiming to hire and retain top talent, they're not going to fit a bell curve!

Middle management often seem to play politics, care more about their careers than the business or their employees/colleagues.
